sources.title: Fast and Furious (1927) | Colorized Public Domain Comedy Classic with Reginald Denny & Barbara Worth
sources.description:
Fast and Furious (1927) is a silent comedy film directed by Melville W. Brown and distributed by Universal Pictures. This restored and colorized public domain edition revives one of the late silent-era comedies that entertained audiences in the roaring twenties. Starring Reginald Denny, a versatile British-American actor known for his athletic charm, the film captures both the humor and energy that defined silent comedy in the years just before sound revolutionized Hollywood.

Plot Summary:
Set against a backdrop of fast cars, quick wits, and the social life of the 1920s, the film follows a story of misadventures in love and ambition. Reginald Denny plays the protagonist whose life quickly spins out of control through misunderstandings, comedic mishaps, and daring escapades. With the help of leading lady Barbara Worth, the plot blends romance with slapstick, portraying the chaotic yet exciting pace of modern life.

Though often overlooked today, Fast and Furious highlights the transition from the carefree silent comedy tradition to the more sophisticated narratives of the late 1920s. Its themes of romance, mistaken identity, and physical humor made it an accessible crowd-pleaser in its time, appealing to audiences eager for lighthearted entertainment during a rapidly modernizing decade.

metadata.Plot: Tom Brown, a wealthy young bachelor fond of speeding, wrecks his car and is aided by Smithfield, whereupon he instantly becomes enamored of the latter's daughter, Ethel. After recuperating from the accident, Tom embarks for California to find the Smithfields. During a traffic jam, he and Smithfield get into an altercation, which results in Tom's tweaking Smithfield's nose; at the Smithfield residence, Tom visits Ethel, who is supervising the creation of a statue dedicated by her father to racing drivers. Only Ethel's and the sculptor's combined efforts prevent a battle with Smithfield. Tom agrees to impersonate Billings, a racing champion, who is to pose for the sculptor and appear at the dedication, and is forced to complete the deception by driving in a race. After numerous adventures he wins the race and the love of Ethel.
